supporting_text: The NAP emphasizes the involvement and full participation of the health, veterinary, agriculture, and other sectors at the federal, provincial, and regional levels in the One Health Approach.
The NAP mentions specific actions in the human health sector, including the development and implementation of a national awareness raising and behavioral change strategy on antimicrobial resistance.
The NAP includes strategies for improving prevention and control of infections in animal health and emphasizes the need for regulations for veterinary antimicrobial utilization.
The NAP addresses environmental aspects by including strategies for improving sanitation and hygiene, which are crucial for controlling AMR.
The NAP includes strategies to phase out the use of antimicrobials as growth promoters in agriculture and to provide appropriate alternatives.
The NAP outlines a Monitoring & Evaluation Plan that includes mechanisms for tracking progress and reporting on the implementation of its objectives.
The NAP specifies various strategic priorities and objectives with timelines for implementation.
The document does not specify quantitative targets for AMR prevalence or antimicrobial use.
The NAP does not mention specific budget allocations for its strategies or actions.
The NAP does not provide an assessment of future budget requirements for its activities.
The NAP mentions the establishment of an Intra-sectoral Core Steering Committee to oversee the development and implementation of the National Policy on AMR.
The NAP includes strategies to update and enforce regulations for human and veterinary antimicrobial utilization.
The NAP emphasizes the inclusion of AMR in school curricula and professional education and training programs for healthcare professionals.
The NAP outlines the development and implementation of a national awareness raising and behavioral change strategy on antimicrobial resistance.
The NAP mentions collaboration with WHO and other international organizations in the development and implementation of AMR strategies.
The NAP includes the establishment of an integrated national AMR surveillance system for monitoring human, animal usage, and resistance.
The NAP emphasizes the need for strengthening surveillance and response capacities to detect and report AMR.
The NAP includes strategies for improving sanitation, hygiene, and infection prevention and control measures.
The NAP mentions the adaptation of international standards to minimize and control AMR.
The NAP includes strategies for updating and enforcing regulations for human and veterinary antimicrobial utilization.
The NAP emphasizes the need for regulations to ensure the rational use of antibiotics.
The NAP encourages collaboration with international partners for research and development in AMR.
